text: The vision of Isaiah the son of Amoz, which he saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem in the days of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah, kings of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hear, O heavens, and give ear, O earth! For the Lord hath spoken: “I have nourished and brought up children, and they have rebelled against Me.
speaker: Narrator

text: The ox knoweth his owner and the ass his master’s crib; but Israel doth not know, My people doth not consider.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Ah, sinful nation, a people laden with iniquity, a seed of evildoers, children that are corrupters! They have forsaken the Lord, they have provoked the Holy One of Israel unto anger, they have gone away backward.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why should ye be stricken anymore? Ye will revolt more and more. The whole head is sick, and the whole heart faint.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the sole of the foot even unto the head, there is no soundness in it, but wounds and bruises and putrefying sores; they have not been closed, neither bound up, neither mollified with ointment.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your country is desolate, your cities are burned with fire; your land, strangers devour it in your presence, and it is desolate, as overthrown by strangers.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the daughter of Zion is left as a cottage in a vineyard, as a shed in a garden of cucumbers, as a besieged city.
speaker: Narrator

text: Unless the Lord of hosts had left unto us a very small remnant, we should have been as Sodom, and we should have been like unto Gomorrah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hear the word of the Lord, ye rulers of Sodom; give ear unto the law of our God, ye people of Gomorrah:
speaker: Narrator

text: “To what purpose is the multitude of your sacrifices unto Me?” saith the Lord. “I am full of the burnt offerings of rams and the fat of fed beasts; and I delight not in the blood of bullocks, or of lambs or of hegoats.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you come to appear before Me, who hath required this from your hand, to tread My courts?
speaker: Narrator

text: Bring no more vain oblations; incense is an abomination unto Me. The new moons and Sabbaths, the calling of assemblies, I cannot endure. It is iniquity, even the solemn meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Your new moons and your appointed feasts My soul hateth; they are a trouble unto Me, I am weary of bearing them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when ye spread forth your hands, I will hide Mine eyes from you; yea, when ye make many prayers, I will not hear; your hands are full of blood.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wash you, make you clean, put away the evil of your doings from before Mine eyes. Cease to do evil,
speaker: Narrator

text: learn to do well. Seek judgment, relieve the oppressed; judge the fatherless, plead for the widow.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Come now, and let us reason together,” saith the Lord. “Though your sins be as scarlet, they shall be as white as snow; though they be red like crimson, they shall be as wool.
speaker: Narrator

text: If ye be willing and obedient, ye shall eat the good of the land;
speaker: Narrator

text: but if ye refuse and rebel, ye shall be devoured with the sword”; for the mouth of the Lord hath spoken it.
speaker: Narrator

text: How the faithful city has become a harlot! It was full of judgment; righteousness lodged in it, but now murderers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thy silver has become dross, thy wine mixed with water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thy princes are rebellious, and companions of thieves; every one loveth bribes, and followeth after rewards. They judge not the fatherless, neither doth the cause of the widow come unto them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore saith the Lord, the Lord of hosts, the Mighty One of Israel: “Ah, I will ease Me of Mine adversaries, and avenge Me of Mine enemies.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I will turn My hand against thee, and wholly purge away thy dross, and take away all thy tin.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will restore thy judges as at the first, and thy counselors as at the beginning. Afterward thou shalt be called the City of Righteousness, the Faithful City.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Zion shall be redeemed with judgment, and her converts with righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the destruction of the transgressors and of the sinners shall be together, and they that forsake the Lord shall be consumed.
speaker: Narrator

text: For ye shall be ashamed of the oaks which ye have desired, and ye shall be confounded for the gardens that ye have chosen.
speaker: Narrator

text: For ye shall be as an oak whose leaf fadeth, and as a garden that hath no water.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the strong shall be as tow, and the maker of it as a spark; and they shall both burn together, and none shall quench them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The word that Isaiah the son of Amoz saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem:
speaker: Narrator

text: And it shall come to pass in the last days that the mountain of the Lord’S house shall be established on the top of the mountains, and shall be exalted above the hills, and all nations shall flow unto it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And many people shall go and say, “Come ye, and let us go up to the mountain of the Lord, to the house of the God of Jacob; and He will teach us of His ways, and we will walk in His paths.” For out of Zion shall go forth the law, and the word of the Lord from Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: And He shall judge among the nations, and shall rebuke many people; and they shall beat their swords into plowshares, and their spears into pruning hooks; nation shall not lift up sword against nation, neither shall they learn war anymore.
speaker: Narrator

text: O house of Jacob, come ye and let us walk in the light of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: For Thou hast forsaken Thy people, the house of Jacob, because they are replenished from the East, and are soothsayers like the Philistines; and they please themselves with the children of strangers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their land also is full of silver and gold, neither is there any end of their treasures; their land is also full of horses, neither is there any end of their chariots.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their land also is full of idols; they worship the work of their own hands, that which their own fingers have made.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the lowly man boweth down, and the great man humbleth himself; therefore forgive them not.
speaker: Narrator

text: Enter into the rock, and hide thee in the dust, for fear of the Lord and for the glory of His majesty.
speaker: Narrator

text: The lofty looks of man shall be humbled, and the haughtiness of men shall be bowed down; and the Lord alone shall be exalted in that day.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the day of the Lord of hosts shall be upon every one that is proud and lofty, and upon every one that is lifted up—and he shall be brought low”
speaker: Narrator

text: and upon all the cedars of Lebanon that are high and lifted up, and upon all the oaks of Bashan;
speaker: Narrator

text: and upon all the high mountains, and upon all the hills that are lifted up;
speaker: Narrator

text: and upon every high tower, and upon every fortified wall;
speaker: Narrator

text: and upon all the ships of Tarshish, and upon all pleasant sights.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the loftiness of man shall be bowed down, and the haughtiness of men shall be made low; and the Lord alone shall be exalted in that day,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the idols He shall utterly abolish.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they shall go into the holes of the rocks, and into the caves of the earth, for fear of the Lord and for the glory of His majesty, when He ariseth to shake terribly the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: In that day a man shall cast away his idols of silver and his idols of gold (which he made each one for himself to worship) to the moles and to the bats,
speaker: Narrator

text: to go into the clefts of the rocks, and into the tops of the ragged rocks, for fear of the Lord and for the glory of His majesty, when He ariseth to shake terribly the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Cease ye from man, whose breath is in his nostrils; for of what account is he?
speaker: Narrator

text: For behold, the Lord, the Lord of hosts, doth take away from Jerusalem and from Judah the stay and the staff, the whole store of bread and the whole store of water,
speaker: Narrator

text: the mighty man and the man of war, the judge and the prophet, and the prudent and the ancient,
speaker: Narrator

text: the captain of fifty and the honorable man, and the counselor and the skilled artificer and the eloquent orator.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And I will give children to be their princes, and babes shall rule over them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the people shall be oppressed, every one by another and every one by his neighbor; the child shall behave himself proudly against the elder, and the base against the honorable.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When a man shall take hold of his brother in the house of his father, saying, “Thou hast clothing; be thou our ruler, and let this ruin be under thy hand,”
speaker: Narrator

text: in that day he shall swear, saying, “I will not be a healer, for in my house is neither bread nor clothing: Make me not a ruler of the people!”
speaker: Narrator

text: For Jerusalem is ruined, and Judah is fallen, because their tongue and their doings are against the Lord, to provoke the eyes of His glory.
speaker: Narrator

text: The show of their countenance doth witness against them, and they declare their sin as Sodom; they hide it not. Woe unto their soul! For they have rewarded evil unto themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Say ye to the righteous that it shall be well with them, for they shall eat the fruits of their doings.
speaker: Narrator

text: Woe unto the wicked! It shall be ill with him, for the reward of his hands shall be given him.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for My people, children are their oppressors, and women rule over them! O My people, they that lead thee cause thee to err, and destroy the way of thy paths.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord standeth up to plead and standeth to judge the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord will enter into judgment with the elders of His people and the princes thereof: “For ye have eaten up the vineyard, and the spoil of the poor is in your houses.
speaker: Narrator

text: What mean ye that ye beat My people to pieces and grind the faces of the poor?” saith the Lord God of hosts.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover the Lord saith: “Because the daughters of Zion are haughty, and walk with stretched forth necks and wanton eyes, walking and mincing as they go, and making a tinkling with their feet,
speaker: Narrator

text: therefore the Lord will smite with a scab the crown of the head of the daughters of Zion, and the Lord will uncover their secret parts.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In that day the Lord will take away the bravery of their tinkling ornaments about their feet, and their hair nets and their round ornaments like the moon,
speaker: Narrator

text: the chains and the bracelets and the spangled ornaments,
speaker: Narrator

text: the bonnets and the ornaments of the legs, and the headbands and the tablets and the earrings,
speaker: Narrator

text: the rings and nose jewels,
speaker: Narrator

text: the changeable suits of apparel and the mantles and the shawls and the crisping pins,
speaker: Narrator

text: the mirrors and the fine linen, and the hoods and the veils.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it shall come to pass that instead of sweet smell there shall be stench; and instead of a girdle, a rent; and instead of wellset hair, baldness; and instead of a sash, a girding of sackcloth; and branding instead of beauty.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thy men shall fall by the sword, and thy mighty in the war.
speaker: Narrator

text: And her gates shall lament and mourn; and she, being desolate, shall sit upon the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: And in that day seven women shall take hold of one man, saying, “We will eat our own bread and wear our own apparel; only let us be called by thy name to take away our reproach.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In that day shall the Branch of the Lord be beautiful and glorious; and the fruit of the earth shall be excellent and comely for those who have escaped of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it shall come to pass that he that is left in Zion and he that remaineth in Jerusalem shall be called holy — even every one who is written among the living in Jerusalem —
speaker: Narrator

text: when the Lord shall have washed away the filth of the daughters of Zion, and shall have purged the blood of Jerusalem from her midst by the spirit of judgment and by the spirit of burning.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord will create upon every dwelling place of Mount Zion, and upon her assemblies, a cloud and smoke by day and the shining of a flaming fire by night; for upon all the glory shall be a defense.
speaker: Narrator

text: And there shall be a tabernacle for shade in the daytime from the heat, and for a place of refuge and for a covert from storm and from rain.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now will I sing to my Well-beloved a song of my Beloved concerning His vineyard: my Well-beloved hath a vineyard on a very fruitful hill.
speaker: Narrator

text: And He fenced it, and gathered out the stones thereof, and planted it with the choicest vine; and built a tower in the midst of it, and also made a wine press therein. And He looked for it to bring forth grapes, and it brought forth wild grapes.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And now, O inhabitants of Jerusalem and men of Judah, judge, I pray you, between Me and My vineyard.
speaker: Narrator

text: What could have been done more to My vineyard than I have not done in it? Why, when I looked for it to bring forth good grapes, brought it forth wild grapes?
speaker: Narrator

text: “And now, I will tell you what I will do to My vineyard: I will take away the hedge thereof, and it shall be eaten up; and break down the wall thereof, and it shall be trodden down.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I will lay it waste; it shall not be pruned nor dug, but there shall come up briers and thorns. I will also command the clouds that they rain no rain upon it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For the vineyard of the Lord of hosts is the house of Israel, and the men of Judah, His pleasant plant. And He looked for judgment, but behold, oppression; for righteousness, but behold, a cry.
speaker: Narrator

text: Woe unto them that join house to house, that lay field to field, till there be no place, that they may be placed alone in the midst of the earth!
speaker: Narrator

text: In mine ears said the Lord of hosts: “In truth many houses shall be desolate, even the great and fair, without inhabitant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yea, ten acres of vineyard shall yield but one bath, and a homer of seed shall yield but an ephah.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Woe unto them that rise up early in the morning, that they may pursue strong drink; that continue until night, till wine inflame them!
speaker: Narrator

text: And the harp and the viol, and the taboret and pipe, and wine are in their feasts; but they regard not the work of the Lord, neither consider the operation of His hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore my people are gone into captivity, because they have no knowledge; and their honorable men are famished, and their multitude dried up with thirst.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore hell hath enlarged herself, and opened her mouth beyond measure; and their glory and their multitude and their pomp, and he that rejoiceth, shall descend into it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the lowly man shall be brought down, and the mighty man shall be humbled, and the eyes of the lofty shall be humbled.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Lord of hosts shall be exalted in judgment, and God who is holy shall be sanctified in righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then shall the lambs feed according to their manner, and the waste places of the fat ones shall strangers eat.
speaker: Narrator

text: Woe unto them that draw along iniquity with cords of vanity, and sin as it were with a cart rope;
speaker: Narrator

text: who say, “Let Him make speed and hasten His work, that we may see it; and let the counsel of the Holy One of Israel draw nigh and come, that we may know it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Woe unto them that call evil good, and good evil; that count darkness as light, and light as darkness; that put bitter for sweet, and sweet for bitter!
speaker: Narrator

text: Woe unto them that are wise in their own eyes, and prudent in their own sight!
speaker: Narrator

text: Woe unto them that are mighty to drink wine, and men of strength to mingle strong drink,
speaker: Narrator

text: who justify the wicked for a reward, and take away the righteousness of the righteous from him!
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore as the fire devoureth the stubble, and the flame consumeth the chaff, so their root shall be rottenness, and their blossom shall go up as dust; because they have cast away the law of the Lord of hosts, and despised the word of the Holy One of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore is the anger of the Lord kindled against His people, and He hath stretched forth His hand against them, and hath smitten them; and the hills did tremble, and their carcasses were torn in the midst of the streets. For all this, His anger is not turned away, but His hand is stretched out still.
speaker: Narrator

text: And He will lift up an ensign to the nations from afar, and will hiss unto them from the end of the earth; and behold, they shall come with speed swiftly.
speaker: Narrator

text: None shall be weary nor stumble among them; none shall slumber nor sleep; neither shall the girdle of their loins be loosed, nor the latchet of their shoes be broken;
speaker: Narrator

text: whose arrows are sharp, and all their bows bent, their horses’ hoofs shall be counted like flint, and their wheels like a whirlwind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their roaring shall be like a lion; they shall roar like young lions; yea, they shall roar and lay hold of the prey, and shall carry it away safe, and none shall deliver it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And in that day they shall roar against them like the roaring of the sea; and if one look unto the land, behold darkness and sorrow; and the light is darkened in the heavens thereof.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the year that King Uzziah died, I saw also the Lord sitting upon a throne, high and lifted up, and His train filled the temple.
speaker: Narrator

text: Above it stood the seraphims; each one had six wings: with two he covered his face, and with two he covered his feet, and with two he flew.
speaker: Narrator

text: And one cried unto another and said, “Holy, holy, holy is the Lord of hosts; the whole earth is full of His glory.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the posts of the door moved at the voice of him that cried, and the house was filled with smoke.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then said I, “Woe is me! For I am undone, because I am a man of unclean lips and I dwell in the midst of a people of unclean lips; for mine eyes have seen the King, the Lord of hosts.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then flew one of the seraphims unto me, having a live coal in his hand, which he had taken with the tongs from off the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he laid it upon my mouth and said, “Lo, this hath touched thy lips; and thine iniquity is taken away, and thy sin purged.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Also I heard the voice of the Lord saying, “Whom shall I send, and who will go for Us?” Then said I, “Here am I. Send me!”
speaker: Narrator

text: And He said, “Go, and tell this people: “‘Hear ye indeed, but understand not; and see ye indeed, but perceive not.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Make the heart of this people fat, and make their ears heavy, and shut their eyes; lest they see with their eyes, and hear with their ears, and understand with their heart, and convert and be healed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then said I, “Lord, how long?” And He answered, “Until the cities be wasted without inhabitant, and the houses without man, and the land be utterly desolate,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the Lord have removed men far away, and there be a great forsaking in the midst of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But yet in it shall be a tenth, and it shall return and shall be eaten, as a teil tree and as an oak whose substance is in them when they cast their leaves: so the holy seed shall be the substance thereof.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And it came to pass in the days of Ahaz the son of Jotham, the son of Uzziah, king of Judah, that Rezin the king of Syria and Pekah the son of Remaliah, king of Israel, went up toward Jerusalem to war against it, but could not prevail against it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it was told the house of David, saying, “Syria is confederate with Ephraim.” And his heart was moved, and the heart of his people, as the trees of the wood are moved with the wind.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then said the Lord unto Isaiah, “Go forth now to meet Ahaz, thou and Shearjashub [that is, The remnant shall return], thy son, at the end of the conduit of the upper pool in the highway of the Fuller’s Field,
speaker: Narrator

text: and say unto him: ‘Take heed, and be quiet. Fear not, neither be fainthearted at the two tails of these smoking firebrands — at the fierce anger of Rezin and Syria, and of the son of Remaliah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because Syria, Ephraim, and the son of Remaliah have taken evil counsel against thee, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Let us go up against Judah and vex it, and let us make a breach therein for us, and set a king in the midst of it, even the son of Tabeel,”
speaker: Narrator

text: thus saith the Lord God: It shall not stand, neither shall it come to pass.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the head of Syria is Damascus, and the head of Damascus is Rezin; and within threescore and five years shall Ephraim be broken, that it be not a people.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the head of Ephraim is Samaria, and the head of Samaria is Remaliah’s son. If ye will not believe, surely ye shall not be established.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover the Lord spoke again unto Ahaz, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Ask thee a sign of the Lord thy God; ask it either in the depth or in the height above.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Ahaz said, “I will not ask, neither will I tempt the Lord.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Isaiah said, “Hear ye now, O house of David! Is it a small thing for you to weary men, but will ye weary my God also?
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore the Lord Himself shall give you a sign: Behold, a virgin shall conceive and bear a Son, and shall call His name Immanuel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Butter and honey shall He eat, that He may know to refuse the evil and choose the good.
speaker: Narrator

text: For before the Child shall know to refuse the evil and choose the good, the land that thou abhorrest shall be forsaken of both her kings.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord shall bring upon thee and upon thy people and upon thy father’s house days that have not come since the day that Ephraim departed from Judah: even the king of Assyria.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And it shall come to pass in that day that the Lord shall hiss for the fly that is in the uttermost part of the rivers of Egypt and for the bee that is in the land of Assyria.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they shall come, and shall rest all of them in the desolate valleys and in the holes of the rocks, and upon all thorns and upon all bushes.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the same day shall the Lord shave with a hired razor (namely, by those beyond the river, by the king of Assyria) the head and the hair of the feet, and it shall also consume the beard.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it shall come to pass in that day that a man shall nourish a young cow and two sheep;
speaker: Narrator

text: and it shall come to pass, for the abundance of milk that they shall give, that he shall eat butter, for butter and honey shall every one eat that is left in the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it shall come to pass in that day in every place where there were a thousand vines worth a thousand silverlings, that it shall be even for briers and thorns.
speaker: Narrator

text: With arrows and with bows shall men come thither, because all the land shall become briers and thorns.
speaker: Narrator

text: And on all hills that shall be dug with the mattock, there shall not be a coming thither for fear of briers and thorns, but it shall be for the sending forth of oxen and for the treading of lesser cattle.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover the Lord said unto me, “Take thee a great scroll, and write in it with a man’s pen concerning Mahershalalhashbaz.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And I took unto me faithful witnesses to attest: Uriah the priest and Zechariah the son of Jeberechiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I went unto the prophetess, and she conceived and bore a son. Then said the Lord to me, “Call his name Mahershalalhashbaz.
speaker: Narrator

text: For before the child shall have knowledge to cry ‘My father,’ and ‘My mother,’ the riches of Damascus and the spoil of Samaria shall be taken away to the king of Assyria.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke also unto me again, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Inasmuch as this people refuseth the waters of Shiloah that flow softly, and rejoice in Rezin and Remaliah’s son,
speaker: Narrator

text: now therefore, behold, the Lord bringeth up upon them the waters of the river, strong and many, even the king of Assyria and all his glory; and he shall come up over all his channels and go over all his banks.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he shall pass through Judah; he shall overflow and go over, he shall reach even to the neck. And the stretching out of his wings shall fill the breadth of thy land, O Immanuel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Associate yourselves, O ye people, yet ye shall be broken in pieces! And give ear, all ye of far countries. Gird yourselves, and ye shall be broken in pieces; gird yourselves, and ye shall be broken in pieces!
speaker: Narrator

text: Take counsel together, and it shall come to nought; speak the word, and it shall not stand, for God is with us.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord spoke thus to me with a strong hand, and instructed me that I should not walk in the way of this people, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Say ye not, ‘A confederacy,’ to all those to whom this people shall say, ‘A confederacy’; neither fear ye their fear, nor be afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sanctify the Lord of hosts Himself; and let Him be your fear, and let Him be your dread.
speaker: Narrator

text: And He shall be for you a sanctuary, but for a stone of stumbling and for a rock of offense to both the houses of Israel, for a trap and for a snare to the inhabitants of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: And many among them shall stumble and fall and be broken, and be snared and be taken.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Bind up the testimony, seal the law among my disciples.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I will wait upon the Lord, who hideth His face from the house of Jacob, and I will look for Him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, I and the children whom the Lord hath given me are for signs and for wonders in Israel from the Lord of hosts, who dwelleth in Mount Zion.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when they shall say unto you, “Seek unto those who have familiar spirits and wizards, who peep and who mutter,” should not a people seek unto their God? For the living, to the dead?
speaker: Narrator

text: To the law and to the testimony! If they speak not according to this word, it is because there is no light in them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they shall pass through it sorely beset and hungry; and it shall come to pass that, when they shall be hungry, they shall fret themselves and curse their king and their God, and look upward;
speaker: Narrator

text: and they shall look unto the earth and behold trouble and darkness, dimness of anguish, and they shall be driven to darkness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nevertheless the dimness shall not be such as was in her vexation, when at the first He lightly afflicted the land of Zebulun and the land of Naphtali, and afterward more grievously afflicted her by the way of the sea, beyond the Jordan, in Galilee of the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people that walked in darkness have seen a great light; they that dwell in the land of the shadow of death, upon them hath the light shined.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou hast multiplied the nation and not increased the joy; they joy before Thee according to the joy in harvest, and as men rejoice when they divide the spoil.
speaker: Narrator

text: For Thou hast broken the yoke of his burden and the staff of his shoulder, the rod of his oppressor, as in the day of Midian.
speaker: Narrator

text: For every battle of the warrior is with confused noise and garments rolled in blood, but this shall be with burning and fuel of fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: For unto us a Child is born, unto us a Son is given; and the government shall be upon His shoulder. And His name shall be called Wonderful, Counselor, The Mighty God, The Everlasting Father, The Prince of Peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: Of the increase of His government and peace there shall be no end, upon the throne of David and upon His Kingdom, to order it and to establish it with judgment and with justice from henceforth even for ever. The zeal of the Lord of hosts will perform this.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord sent a word into Jacob, and it hath lighted upon Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: And all the people shall know—even Ephraim and the inhabitant of Samaria” that say in the pride and stoutness of heart:
speaker: Narrator

text: “The bricks are fallen down, but we will build with hewn stones; the sycamores are cut down, but we will change them into cedars.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore the Lord shall set up the adversaries of Rezin against him and join his enemies together,
speaker: Narrator

text: the Syrians before and the Philistines behind; and they shall devour Israel with open mouth. For all this His anger is not turned away, but His hand is stretched out still.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the people turneth not unto Him that smiteth them, neither do they seek the Lord of hosts.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore the Lord will cut off from Israel head and tail, branch and rush, in one day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The ancient and honorable, he is the head; and the prophet that teacheth lies, he is the tail.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the leaders of this people cause them to err, and they that are led by them are destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore the Lord shall have no joy in their young men, neither shall have mercy on their fatherless and widows; for every one is a hypocrite and an evildoer, and every mouth speaketh folly. For all this His anger is not turned away, but His hand is stretched out still.
speaker: Narrator

text: For wickedness burneth as the fire; it shall devour the briers and thorns, and shall kindle in the thickets of the forest, and they shall mount up like the lifting up of smoke.
speaker: Narrator

text: Through the wrath of the Lord of hosts is the land darkened, and the people shall be as the fuel of the fire; no man shall spare his brother.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he shall snatch on the right hand and be hungry; and he shall eat on the left hand, and they shall not be satisfied; they shall eat every man the flesh of his own arm.
speaker: Narrator

text: Manasseh, Ephraim; and Ephraim, Manasseh; and they together shall be against Judah. For all this His anger is not turned away, but His hand is stretched out still.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Woe unto them that decree unrighteous decrees, and that write grievousness which they have prescribed
speaker: Narrator

text: to turn aside the needy from judgment and to take away the right from the poor of My people, that widows may be their prey, and that they may rob the fatherless!
speaker: Narrator

text: And what will ye do in the day of visitation, and in the desolation which shall come from far? To whom will ye flee for help? And where will ye leave your glory?
speaker: Narrator

text: Without Me they shall bow down under the prisoners, and they shall fall under the slain.” For all this His anger is not turned away, but His hand is stretched out still.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Woe to the Assyrian, the rod of Mine anger, and the staff in their hand is Mine indignation!
speaker: Narrator

text: I will send him against a hypocritical nation, and against the people of My wrath will I give him a charge, to take the spoil and to take the prey, and to tread them down like the mire of the streets.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet he meaneth not so, neither doth his heart think so; but it is in his heart to destroy and cut off nations not a few.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he saith, ‘Are not my princes altogether kings?
speaker: Narrator

text: Is not Calno as Carchemish? Is not Hamath as Arpad? Is not Samaria as Damascus?
speaker: Narrator

text: As my hand hath found the kingdoms of the idols and whose graven images excelled them of Jerusalem and of Samaria,
speaker: Narrator

text: shall I not, as I have done unto Samaria and her idols, so do to Jerusalem and her idols?’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore it shall come to pass when the Lord hath performed His whole work upon Mount Zion and on Jerusalem: “I will punish the fruit of the stout heart of the king of Assyria and the glory of his high looks.
speaker: Narrator

text: For he saith, “‘By the strength of my hand I have done it, and by my wisdom, for I am prudent; and I have removed the bounds of the people and have robbed their treasures, and I have put down the inhabitants like a valiant man.
speaker: Narrator

text: And my hand hath found as a nest the riches of the people, and as one gathereth eggs that are left, have I gathered all the earth; and there was none that moved the wing, or opened the mouth, or peeped.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Shall the ax boast itself against him that heweth therewith? Or shall the saw magnify itself against him that shaketh it? As if the rod should shake itself against them that lift it up, or as if the staff should lift up itself, as if it were no wood!
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore shall the Lord, the Lord of hosts, send among His fat ones leanness; and under His glory He shall kindle a burning like the burning of a fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Light of Israel shall be for a fire and his Holy One for a flame; and it shall burn and devour his thorns and his briers in one day,
speaker: Narrator

text: and shall consume the glory of his forest and of his fruitful field, both soul and body; and they shall be as when a standardbearer fainteth.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the rest of the trees of his forest shall be few, that a child may write them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it shall come to pass in that day that the remnant of Israel, and such as have escaped of the house of Jacob, shall no more again depend upon him that smote them, but shall stand upon the Lord, the Holy One of Israel, in truth.
speaker: Narrator

text: The remnant shall return, even the remnant of Jacob, unto the mighty God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For though thy people Israel be as the sand of the sea, yet a remnant of them shall return; the consuming decreed shall overflow with righteousness.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord God of hosts shall cause a consuming, even determined, in the midst of all the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore thus saith the Lord God of hosts: “O My people that dwellest in Zion, be not afraid of the Assyrian. He shall smite thee with a rod and shall lift up his staff against thee, after the manner of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: For yet a very little while and the indignation shall cease, and Mine anger in their destruction.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord of hosts shall stir up a scourge for him according to the slaughter of Midian at the rock of Oreb; and as His rod was upon the sea, so shall He lift it up after the manner of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it shall come to pass in that day, that his burden shall be taken away from off thy shoulder and his yoke from off thy neck, and the yoke shall be destroyed because of the anointing.
speaker: Narrator

text: He is come to Aiath, he is passed to Migron; at Michmash he hath laid up his baggage.
speaker: Narrator

text: They are gone over the passage; they have taken up their lodging at Geba. Ramah is afraid; Gibeah of Saul is fled.
speaker: Narrator

text: Lift up thy voice, O daughter of Gallim; cause it to be heard unto Laish, O poor Anathoth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Madmenah is removed; the inhabitants of Gebim gather themselves to flee.
speaker: Narrator

text: As yet shall he remain at Nob that day; he shall shake his hand against the mount of the daughter of Zion, the hill of Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, the Lord, the Lord of hosts, shall lop the bough with terror; and the high ones of stature shall be hewn down, and the haughty shall be humbled.
speaker: Narrator

text: And He shall cut down the thickets of the forest with iron, and Lebanon shall fall by a mighty one.
speaker: Narrator

text: And there shall come forth a Rod out of the stem of Jesse, and a Branch shall grow out of his roots.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Spirit of the Lord shall rest upon Him—the Spirit of wisdom and understanding, the Spirit of counsel and might, the Spirit of knowledge and of the fear of the Lord”
speaker: Narrator

text: and shall make Him of quick understanding in the fear of the Lord; and He shall not judge after the sight of His eyes, neither reprove after the hearing of His ears.
speaker: Narrator

text: But with righteousness shall He judge the poor, and reprove with equity for the meek of the earth; and He shall smite the earth with the rod of His mouth, and with the breath of His lips shall He slay the wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text: And righteousness shall be the girdle of His loins, and faithfulness the girdle of His reins.
speaker: Narrator

text: “The wolf also shall dwell with the lamb, and the leopard shall lie down with the kid; and the calf and the young lion and the fatling together; and a little child shall lead them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the cow and the bear shall feed; their young ones shall lie down together; and the lion shall eat straw like the ox.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the sucking child shall play on the hole of the asp, and the weaned child shall put his hand on the adder’s den.
speaker: Narrator

text: They shall not hurt nor destroy in all My holy mountain; for the earth shall be full of the knowledge of the Lord, as the waters cover the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And in that day there shall be a Root of Jesse, who shall stand for an ensign of the people; to It shall the Gentiles seek, and His rest shall be glorious.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And it shall come to pass in that day that the Lord shall set His hand again the second time to recover the remnant of His people who shall be left, from Assyria, and from Egypt, and from Pathros, and from Cush, and from Elam, and from Shinar, and from Hamath, and from the islands of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: And He shall set up an ensign for the nations, and shall assemble the outcasts of Israel, and gather together the dispersed of Judah from the four corners of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: The envy also of Ephraim shall depart, and the adversaries of Judah shall be cut off; Ephraim shall not envy Judah, and Judah shall not vex Ephraim.
speaker: Narrator

text: But they shall fly upon the shoulders of the Philistines toward the west; they shall despoil them of the east together. They shall lay their hand upon Edom and Moab, and the children of Ammon shall obey them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord shall utterly destroy the tongue of the Egyptian Sea; and with His mighty wind shall He shake His hand over the river, and shall smite it in the seven streams and make men go over dryshod.
speaker: Narrator

text: And there shall be a highway for the remnant of His people who shall be left from Assyria, as it was to Israel in the day that he came up out of the land of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: And in that day thou shalt say: “O Lord, I will praise Thee; though Thou wast angry with me, Thine anger is turned away, and Thou comforted me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, God is my salvation; I will trust and not be afraid; for the Lord Jehovah is my strength and my song; He also has become my salvation.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore with joy shall ye draw water out of the wells of salvation;
speaker: Narrator

text: and in that day shall ye say: “Praise the Lord! Call upon His name! Declare His doings among the people; make mention that His name is exalted.
speaker: Narrator

text: Sing unto the Lord, for He hath done excellent things; this is known in all the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Cry out and shout, thou inhabitant of Zion! For great is the Holy One of Israel in the midst of thee.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The burden of Babylon, which Isaiah the son of Amoz saw:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Lift ye up a banner upon the high mountain; exalt the voice unto them, shake the hand, that they may go into the gates of the nobles.
speaker: Narrator

text: I have commanded My sanctified ones; I have also called My mighty ones for Mine anger, even them that rejoice in My highness.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The noise of a multitude in the mountains, as of a great people! A tumultuous noise of the kingdoms of nations gathered together! The Lord of hosts mustereth the host of the battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: They come from a far country, from the end of heaven, even the Lord and the weapons of His indignation, to destroy the whole land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Howl ye, for the day of the Lord is at hand! It shall come as a destruction from the Almighty.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore shall all hands be faint, and every man’s heart shall melt.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they shall be afraid; pangs and sorrows shall take hold of them. They shall be in pain as a woman that travaileth; they shall be amazed one at another; their faces shall be as flames.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, the day of the Lord cometh, cruel, both with wrath and fierce anger, to lay the land desolate; and He shall destroy the sinners thereof out of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the stars of heaven and the constellations thereof shall not give their light; the sun shall be darkened in his going forth, and the moon shall not cause her light to shine.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And I will punish the world for their evil and the wicked for their iniquity; and I will cause the arrogance of the proud to cease, and will lay low the haughtiness of the terrible.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will make a man more precious than fine gold, even a man than the golden wedge of Ophir.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore I will shake the heavens, and the earth shall remove out of her place, in the wrath of the Lord of hosts and in the day of His fierce anger.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it shall be as the chased roe, and as a sheep that no man taketh up; they shall every man turn to his own people, and flee every one into his own land.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every one that is found shall be thrust through; and every one that is joined unto them shall fall by the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their children also shall be dashed to pieces before their eyes; their houses shall be despoiled and their wives ravished.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Behold, I will stir up the Medes against them, who shall not regard silver; and as for gold, they shall not delight in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their bows also shall dash the young men to pieces; and they shall have no pity on the fruit of the womb; their eye shall not spare children.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Babylon, the glory of kingdoms, the beauty of the Chaldeans’ excellency, shall be as when God overthrew Sodom and Gomorrah.
speaker: Narrator

text: It shall never be inhabited, neither shall it be dwelt in from generation to generation; neither shall the Arabian pitch tent there, neither shall the shepherds make their fold there.
speaker: Narrator

text: But wild beasts of the desert shall lie there, and their houses shall be full of doleful creatures; and owls shall dwell there, and satyrs shall dance there.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the wild beasts of the islands shall cry in their desolate houses, and dragons in their pleasant palaces; and her time is near to come, and her days shall not be prolonged.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord will have mercy on Jacob, and will yet choose Israel and set them in their own land; and the strangers shall be joined with them, and they shall cleave to the house of Jacob.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the people shall take them and bring them to their place, and the house of Israel shall possess them in the land of the Lord for servants and handmaids; and they shall take them captive whose captives they were, and they shall rule over their oppressors.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it shall come to pass in the day that the Lord shall give thee rest from thy sorrow and from thy fear and from the hard bondage wherein thou wast made to serve,
speaker: Narrator

text: that thou shalt take up this proverb against the king of Babylon, and say: “How hath the oppressor ceased! The golden city ceased!
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord hath broken the staff of the wicked and the scepter of the rulers.
speaker: Narrator

text: He who smote the people in wrath with a continual stroke, he that ruled the nations in anger, is persecuted, and none hindereth.
speaker: Narrator

text: The whole earth is at rest and is quiet; they break forth into singing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yea, the fir trees rejoice at thee, and the cedars of Lebanon, saying, ‘Since thou art laid down, no hewer has come up against us.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Hell from beneath is moved for thee to meet thee at thy coming; it stirreth up the dead for thee, even all the chief ones of the earth; it hath raised up from their thrones all the kings of the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: All they shall speak and say unto thee: ‘Art thou also become weak as we? Art thou become like unto us?’
speaker: Narrator

text: Thy pomp is brought down to the grave, and the noise of thy viols; the worm is spread under thee, and the worms cover thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: “How art thou fallen from heaven, O Lucifer, son of the morning! How art thou cut down to the ground, who didst weaken the nations!
speaker: Narrator

text: For thou hast said in thine heart, ‘I will ascend into heaven, I will exalt my throne above the stars of God; I will sit also upon the mount of the congregation, in the sides of the north.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will ascend above the heights of the clouds; I will be like the Most High.’
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet thou shalt be brought down to hell, to the sides of the pit.
speaker: Narrator

text: They that see thee shall narrowly look upon thee and consider thee, saying, ‘Is this the man that made the earth to tremble, that did shake kingdoms,
speaker: Narrator

text: that made the world as a wilderness and destroyed the cities thereof, that opened not the house of his prisoners?’
speaker: Narrator

text: All the kings of the nations, even all of them, lie in glory, every one in his own house.
speaker: Narrator

text: But thou art cast out of thy grave like an abominable branch, and as the raiment of those that are slain, thrust through with a sword, that go down to the stones of the pit, as a carcass trodden under feet.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou shalt not be joined with them in burial, because thou hast destroyed thy land and slain thy people. The seed of evildoers shall never be renowned.
speaker: Narrator

text: Prepare slaughter for his children for the iniquity of their fathers, that they do not rise, nor possess the land, nor fill the face of the world with cities.”
speaker: Narrator

text: “For I will rise up against them,” saith the Lord of hosts, “and cut off from Babylon the name and remnant, and son and grandson,” saith the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “I will also make it a possession for the bittern, and pools of water; and I will sweep it with the besom of destruction,” saith the Lord of hosts.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord of hosts hath sworn, saying, “Surely as I have thought, so shall it come to pass, and as I have purposed, so shall it stand;
speaker: Narrator

text: that I will break the Assyrian in My land, and upon My mountains tread him under foot. Then shall his yoke depart from off them, and his burden depart from off their shoulders.”
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the purpose that is purposed upon the whole earth, and this is the hand that is stretched out upon all the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord of hosts hath purposed, and who shall disannul it? And His hand is stretched out, and who shall turn it back?
speaker: Narrator

text: In the year that King Ahaz died was this burden:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Rejoice not thou, whole Philistia, because the rod of him that smote thee is broken; for out of the serpent’s root shall come forth an adder, and his fruit shall be a fiery flying serpent.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the firstborn of the poor shall feed, and the needy shall lie down in safety; and I will kill thy root with famine, and he shall slay thy remnant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Howl, O gate! Cry, O city! Thou, whole Philistia art dissolved! For there shall come from the north a smoke, and none shall be alone in his appointed times.”
speaker: Narrator

text: What shall one then answer the messengers of the nation? “That the Lord hath founded Zion, and the poor of His people shall trust in it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The burden of Moab: Because in the night Ar of Moab is laid waste and brought to silence, because in the night Kir of Moab is laid waste and brought to silence,
speaker: Narrator

text: he is gone up to Bajith and to Dibon, the high places, to weep. Moab shall howl over Nebo and over Medeba; on all their heads shall be baldness and every beard cut off.
speaker: Narrator

text: In their streets they shall gird themselves with sackcloth; on the tops of their houses and in their streets every one shall howl, weeping abundantly.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Heshbon shall cry, and Elealeh; their voice shall be heard even unto Jahaz; therefore the armed soldiers of Moab shall cry out; his life shall be grievous unto him.
speaker: Narrator

text: “My heart shall cry out for Moab; his fugitives shall flee unto Zoar, a heifer of three years old; for by the mounting up of Luhith with weeping shall they go up; for in the way of Horonaim they shall raise up a cry of destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the waters of Nimrim shall be desolate; for the hay is withered away, the grass faileth, there is no green thing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore the abundance they have gotten, and that which they have laid up shall they carry away to the Brook of the Willows.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the cry is gone round about the borders of Moab; the howling thereof unto Eglaim and the howling thereof unto Beerelim.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the waters of Dimon shall be full of blood; for I will bring more upon Dimon, lions upon him that escapeth from Moab and upon the remnant of the land.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Send ye the lamb to the ruler of the land, from Sela to the wilderness, unto the mount of the daughter of Zion.
speaker: Narrator

text: For it shall be that as a wandering bird cast out of the nest, so the daughters of Moab shall be at the fords of Arnon.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take counsel, execute judgment; make thy shadow as the night in the midst of the noonday; hide the outcasts, betray not him that wandereth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Let Mine outcasts dwell with thee, Moab; be thou a covert to them from the face of the despoiler; for the extortioner is at an end, the despoiler ceaseth, the oppressors are consumed out of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text: And in mercy shall the throne be established; and He shall sit upon it in truth in the tabernacle of David, judging and seeking judgment and hastening righteousness.”
speaker: Narrator

text: We have heard of the pride of Moab—he is very proud” even of his haughtiness and his pride and his wrath; but his lies shall not be so.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore shall Moab howl for Moab, every one shall howl; for the foundations of Kirhareseth shall ye mourn; surely they are stricken.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the fields of Heshbon languish, and the vine of Sibmah; the lords of the heathen have broken down the principal plants thereof. They are come even unto Jazer; they wandered through the wilderness; her branches are stretched out; they are gone over the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore I will bewail with the weeping of Jazer the vine of Sibmah; I will water thee with my tears, O Heshbon and Elealeh, for upon thy summer fruits and upon thy harvest the shouting has fallen.
speaker: Narrator

text: And gladness is taken away and joy out of the plentiful field; and in the vineyards there shall be no singing, neither shall there be shouting. The treaders shall tread out no wine in their presses; I have made their vintage shouting to cease.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore my heart shall sound like a harp for Moab, and mine inward parts for Kirharesh.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it shall come to pass, when it is seen that Moab is weary on the high place, that he shall come to his sanctuary to pray; but he shall not prevail.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the word that the Lord hath spoken concerning Moab since that time.
speaker: Narrator

text: But now the Lord hath spoken, saying, “Within three years, as the years of a hireling, and the glory of Moab shall be contemned with all that great multitude; and the remnant shall be very small and feeble.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The burden of Damascus: “Behold, Damascus is taken away from being a city, and it shall be a ruinous heap.
speaker: Narrator

text: The cities of Aroer are forsaken; they shall be for flocks, which shall lie down, and none shall make them afraid.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fortress also shall cease from Ephraim, and the kingdom from Damascus and the remnant of Syria; they shall be as the glory of the children of Israel,” saith the Lord of hosts.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And in that day it shall come to pass that the glory of Jacob shall be made thin, and the fatness of his flesh shall wax lean.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it shall be as when the harvestman gathereth the corn and reapeth the ears with his arm; and it shall be as he that gathereth ears in the Valley of Rephaim.
speaker: Narrator

text: Yet gleaning grapes shall be left in it, as the shaking of an olive tree, two or three berries in the top of the uppermost bough, four or five in the outmost fruitful branches thereof,” saith the Lord God of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that day shall a man look to his Maker, and his eyes shall have respect for the Holy One of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he shall not look to the altars, the work of his hands, neither shall respect that which his fingers have made, either the Asherah poles or the sun images.
speaker: Narrator

text: In that day shall his strong cities be as a forsaken bough and an uppermost branch, which they left because of the children of Israel; and there shall be desolation.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because thou hast forgotten the God of thy salvation and hast not been mindful of the Rock of thy strength, therefore shalt thou plant pleasant plants, and shalt set them with strange slips.
speaker: Narrator

text: In that day shalt thou make thy plant to grow, and in the morning shalt thou make thy seed to flourish; but the harvest shall be a heap in the day of grief and of desperate sorrow.
speaker: Narrator

text: Woe to the multitude of many people, who make a noise like the noise of the seas, and to the rushing of nations, that make a rushing like the rushing of mighty waters!
speaker: Narrator

text: The nations shall rush like the rushing of many waters; but God shall rebuke them, and they shall flee far off, and shall be chased as the chaff of the mountains before the wind and like a rolling thing before the whirlwind.
speaker: Narrator

text: And behold, at eventide, trouble; and before the morning, he is no more. This is the portion of them that despoil us, and the lot of them that rob us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Woe to the land shadowing with wings, which is beyond the rivers of Ethiopia,
speaker: Narrator

text: that sendeth ambassadors by the sea, even in vessels of bulrushes upon the waters, saying, “Go, ye swift messengers, to a nation scattered and peeled, to a people terrible from their beginning hitherto; a nation meted out and trodden down, whose land the rivers have spoiled!”
speaker: Narrator

text: All ye inhabitants of the world and dwellers on the earth, see ye, when he lifteth up an ensign on the mountains; and when He bloweth a trumpet, hear ye.
speaker: Narrator

text: For so the Lord said unto me: “I will take My rest, and I will consider in My dwelling place, like a clear heat upon herbs and like a cloud of dew in the heat of harvest.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For before the harvest, when the bud is perfect and the sour grape is ripening in the flower, He shall both cut off the sprigs with pruning hooks, and take away and cut down the branches.
speaker: Narrator

text: They shall be left together for the fowls of the mountains and to the beasts of the earth; and the fowls shall summer upon them, and all the beasts of the earth shall winter upon them.
speaker: Narrator

text: In that time shall a present be brought unto the Lord of hosts of a people scattered and peeled, and from a people terrible from their beginning hitherto, a nation meted out and trodden under foot, whose land the rivers have spoiled—to the place of the name of the Lord of hosts, the mount Zion.
speaker: Narrator

text: The burden of Egypt: Behold, the Lord rideth upon a swift cloud, and shall come into Egypt; and the idols of Egypt shall be moved at His presence, and the heart of Egypt shall melt in the midst of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And I will set the Egyptians against the Egyptians; and they shall fight every one against his brother and every one against his neighbor, city against city, and kingdom against kingdom.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the spirit of Egypt shall fail in the midst thereof; and I will destroy the counsel thereof; and they shall seek the idols and the charmers, and them that have familiar spirits and the wizards.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Egyptians will I give over into the hand of a cruel lord, and a fierce king shall rule over them,” saith the Lord, the Lord of hosts.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the waters shall fail from the sea, and the river shall be wasted and dried up.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they shall turn the rivers far away, and the brooks of defense shall be emptied and dried up; the reeds and flags shall wither.
speaker: Narrator

text: The paper reeds by the brooks, by the mouth of the brooks, and every thing sown by the brooks shall wither, be driven away, and be no more.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fishers also shall mourn, and all they that cast hook into the brooks shall lament, and they that spread nets upon the waters shall languish.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover they that work in fine flax and they that weave network shall be confounded.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they shall be broken in the purposes thereof, all that make sluices and ponds for fish.
speaker: Narrator

text: Surely the princes of Zoan are fools; the counsel of the wise counselors of Pharaoh has become brutish. How say ye unto Pharaoh, “I am the son of the wise, the son of ancient kings”?
speaker: Narrator

text: Where are they? Where are thy wise men? And let them tell thee now, and let them know what the Lord of hosts hath purposed upon Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: The princes of Zoan are become fools; the princes of Noph are deceived; they have also seduced Egypt, even they that are the stay of the tribes thereof.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord hath mingled a perverse spirit in the midst thereof; and they have caused Egypt to err in every work thereof, as a drunken man staggereth in his vomit.
speaker: Narrator

text: Neither shall there be any work for Egypt, which the head or tail, branch or rush, may do.
speaker: Narrator

text: In that day shall Egypt be like unto women; and it shall be afraid and fear, because of the shaking of the hand of the Lord of hosts, which He shaketh over it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the land of Judah shall be a terror unto Egypt; every one that maketh mention thereof shall be afraid in himself, because of the counsel of the Lord of hosts, which He hath determined against it.
speaker: Narrator

text: In that day shall five cities in the land of Egypt speak the language of Canaan and swear to the Lord of hosts; one shall be called the City of Destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text: In that day shall there be an altar to the Lord in the midst of the land of Egypt and a pillar at the border thereof to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it shall be for a sign and for a witness unto the Lord of hosts in the land of Egypt; for they shall cry unto the Lord because of the oppressors, and He shall send them a savior and a great one, and He shall deliver them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord shall be known to Egypt, and the Egyptians shall know the Lord in that day and shall do sacrifice and oblation; yea, they shall vow a vow unto the Lord and perform it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord shall smite Egypt; He shall smite and heal it; and they shall return even to the Lord, and He shall be entreated by them and shall heal them.
speaker: Narrator

text: In that day shall there be a highway out of Egypt to Assyria, and the Assyrian shall come into Egypt and the Egyptian into Assyria, and the Egyptians shall serve with the Assyrians.
speaker: Narrator

text: In that day shall Israel be the third with Egypt and with Assyria, even a blessing in the midst of the land,
speaker: Narrator

text: whom the Lord of hosts shall bless, saying, “Blessed be Egypt My people, and Assyria the work of My hands, and Israel Mine inheritance.”
speaker: Narrator

text: In the year that Tartan came unto Ashdod (when Sargon the king of Assyria sent him), and fought against Ashdod and took it,
speaker: Narrator

text: at the same time spoke the Lord by Isaiah the son of Amoz, saying, “Go, and loose the sackcloth from off thy loins, and put off thy shoe from thy foot.” And he did so, walking naked and barefoot.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said, “As My servant Isaiah hath walked naked and barefoot three years for a sign and wonder upon Egypt and upon Ethiopia,
speaker: Narrator

text: so shall the king of Assyria lead away the Egyptians prisoners and the Ethiopians captives, young and old, naked and barefoot, even with their buttocks uncovered, to the shame of Egypt.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they shall be afraid and ashamed of Ethiopia their expectation and of Egypt their glory.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the inhabitants of this isle shall say in that day, ‘Behold, such is our expectation wherever we flee for help to be delivered from the king of Assyria! And how shall we escape?’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The burden of the Desert of the Sea: As whirlwinds in the South pass through, so it cometh from the desert, from a terrible land.
speaker: Narrator

text: A grievous vision is declared unto me; the treacherous dealer dealeth treacherously, and the spoiler spoileth. Go up, O Elam! Besiege, O Media! All the sighing thereof have I made to cease.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore are my loins filled with pain; pangs have taken hold upon me, as the pangs of a woman that travaileth. I was bowed down at the hearing of it; I was dismayed at the seeing of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: My heart panted, fearfulness affrighted me; the night of my pleasure hath He turned into fear unto me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Prepare the table, watch in the watchtower, eat, drink; arise, ye princes and anoint the shield.
speaker: Narrator

text: For thus hath the Lord said unto me: “Go, set a watchman, let him declare what he seeth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And he saw a chariot with a couple of horsemen, a chariot of asses and a chariot of camels; and he hearkened diligently with much heed.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he cried, “A lion! My lord, I stand continually upon the watchtower in the daytime, and I am set at my post whole nights.
speaker: Narrator

text: And behold, here cometh a chariot of men with a couple of horsemen!” And he answered and said, “Babylon is fallen, is fallen! And all the graven images of her gods He hath broken unto the ground!”
speaker: Narrator

text: O my threshing and the corn of my floor, that which I have heard of the Lord of hosts, the God of Israel, have I declared unto you.
speaker: Narrator

text: The burden of Dumah: He calleth to me out of Seir, “Watchman, what of the night? Watchman, what of the night?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The watchman said, “The morning cometh, and also the night. If ye will inquire, inquire ye; return, come.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The burden upon Arabia: In the forest in Arabia shall ye lodge, O ye traveling companies of Dedanites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The inhabitants of the land of Tema brought water to him that was thirsty; they were ready with their bread for him that fled.
speaker: Narrator

text: For they fled from the swords, from the drawn sword, and from the bent bow and from the grievousness of war.
speaker: Narrator

text: For thus hath the Lord said unto me: “Within a year, according to the years of a hireling, all the glory of Kedar shall fail.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the residue of the number of archers, the mighty men of the children of Kedar, shall be diminished. For the Lord God of Israel hath spoken it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The burden of the Valley of Vision: What aileth thee now, that thou art wholly gone up to the housetops?
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou that art full of stirrings, a tumultuous city, a joyous city; thy slain men are not slain with the sword, nor dead in battle.
speaker: Narrator

text: All thy rulers have fled together; they are bound by the archers. All that are found in thee are bound together, who have fled from afar.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore said I, “Look away from me; I will be bitter in weeping. Labor not to comfort me, because of the despoiling of the daughter of my people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For it is a day of trouble and of treading down, and of perplexity by the Lord God of hosts in the Valley of Vision, breaking down the walls, and of crying to the mountains.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Elam bore the quiver with chariots of men and horsemen, and Kir uncovered the shield.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it shall come to pass that thy choicest valleys shall be full of chariots, and the horsemen shall set themselves in array at the gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: And He uncovered the covering of Judah, and thou didst look in that day to the armor of the House of the Forest.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ye have seen also the breaches of the City of David, that they are many; and ye gathered together the waters of the lower pool.
speaker: Narrator

text: And ye have numbered the houses of Jerusalem, and the houses have ye broken down to fortify the wall.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ye made also a ditch between the two walls for the water of the old pool; but ye have not looked unto the Maker thereof, neither had respect unto Him that fashioned it long ago.
speaker: Narrator

text: And in that day did the Lord God of hosts call to weeping and to mourning, and to baldness and to girding with sackcloth.
speaker: Narrator

text: But behold, joy and gladness, slaying oxen and killing sheep, eating flesh and drinking wine! “Let us eat and drink, for tomorrow we shall die!”
speaker: Narrator

text: And it was revealed in mine ears by the Lord of hosts: “Surely this iniquity shall not be purged from you till ye die,” saith the Lord God of hosts.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus saith the Lord God of hosts: “Go, get thee unto this treasurer, even unto Shebna, who is over the house, and say:
speaker: Narrator

text: What hast thou here? And whom hast thou here, that thou hast hewed thee out a sepulcher here, as he that heweth him out a sepulcher on high and that carves out a habitation for himself in a rock?
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, the Lord will carry thee away with a mighty captivity, and will surely cover thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will surely violently turn and toss thee like a ball into a large country. There shalt thou die, and there the chariots of thy glory shall be the shame of thy lord’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I will drive thee from thy station, and from thy state shall he pull thee down.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And it shall come to pass in that day that I will call My servant Eliakim the son of Hilkiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I will clothe him with thy robe and strengthen him with thy girdle, and I will commit thy government into his hand; and he shall be a father to the inhabitants of Jerusalem and to the house of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the key of the house of David will I lay upon his shoulder; so he shall open and none shall shut, and he shall shut and none shall open.
speaker: Narrator

text: And I will fasten him as a nail in a sure place, and he shall be for a glorious throne to his father’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they shall hang upon him all the glory of his father’s house, the offspring and the issue, all vessels of small quantity, from the vessels of cups even to all the vessels of flagons.
speaker: Narrator

text: In that day,” saith the Lord of hosts, “shall the nail that is fastened in the sure place be removed and be cut down and fall, and the burden that was upon it shall be cut off; for the Lord hath spoken it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The burden of Tyre: Howl, ye ships of Tarshish! For it is laid waste, so that there is no house, no entering in; from the land of Cyprus it is revealed to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be still, ye inhabitants of the isle, thou whom the merchants of Sidon that pass over the sea have replenished.
speaker: Narrator

text: And by great waters the seed of Shihor, the harvest of the river, is her revenue; and she is a mart of nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: Be thou ashamed, O Sidon; for the sea hath spoken, even the strength of the sea, saying, “I travail not, nor bring forth children, neither do I nourish up young men nor bring up virgins.”
speaker: Narrator

text: As at the report concerning Egypt, so shall they be sorely pained at the report of Tyre.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pass ye over to Tarshish; howl, ye inhabitants of the isle!
speaker: Narrator

text: Is this your joyous city, whose antiquity is of ancient days? Her own feet shall carry her afar off to sojourn.
speaker: Narrator

text: Who hath taken this counsel against Tyre, the crowning city, whose merchants are princes, whose traffickers are the honorableof the earth?
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord of hosts hath purposed it, to stain the pride of all glory, and to bring into contempt all the honorable of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pass through thy land as a river, O daughter of Tarshish; there is no more strength.
speaker: Narrator

text: He stretched out His hand over the sea, He shook the kingdoms; the Lord hath given a commandment against the merchant city, to destroy the strongholds thereof.
speaker: Narrator

text: And He said, “Thou shalt no more rejoice, O thou oppressed virgin, daughter of Sidon. Arise, pass over to Cyprus; there also shalt thou have no rest.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold the land of the Chaldeans. This people was not, till the Assyrian founded it for those who dwell in the wilderness. They set up the towers thereof, they raised up the palaces thereof, and he brought it to ruin.
speaker: Narrator

text: Howl, ye ships of Tarshish, for your strength is laid waste!
speaker: Narrator

text: And it shall come to pass in that day that Tyre shall be forgotten seventy years, according to the days of one king; after the end of seventy years shall Tyre sing as a harlot.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take a harp, go about the city, thou harlot that hast been forgotten; make sweet melody, sing many songs, that thou mayest be remembered.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And it shall come to pass, after the end of seventy years, that the Lord will visit Tyre; and she shall turn to her hire and shall commit fornication with all the kingdoms of the world upon the face of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: And her merchandise and her hire shall be holiness to the Lord. It shall not be treasured nor laid up, for her merchandise shall be for them that dwell before the Lord, to eat sufficiently and for durable clothing.
speaker: Narrator

text: Behold, the Lord maketh the earth empty and maketh it waste, and turneth it upside down, and scattereth abroad the inhabitants thereof.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it shall be, as with the people, so with the priest; as with the servant, so with his master; as with the maid, so with her mistress; as with the buyer, so with the seller; as with the lender, so with the borrower; as with the taker of interest, so with the giver of interest to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: The land shall be utterly emptied and utterly despoiled; for the Lord hath spoken this word.
speaker: Narrator

text: The earth mourneth and fadeth away; the world languisheth and fadeth away; the haughty people of the earth do languish.
speaker: Narrator

text: The earth also is defiled under the inhabitants thereof, because they have transgressed the laws, changed the ordinance, broken the everlasting covenant.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore hath the curse devoured the earth, and they that dwell therein are desolate; therefore the inhabitants of the earth are burned, and few men left.
speaker: Narrator

text: The new wine mourneth, the vine languisheth, all the merryhearted do sigh.
speaker: Narrator

text: The mirth of taborets ceaseth, the noise of them that rejoice endeth, the joy of the harp ceaseth.
speaker: Narrator

text: They shall not drink wine with a song; strong drink shall bebitter to them that drink it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The city of confusion is broken down; every house is shut up, that no man may come in.
speaker: Narrator

text: There is a crying for wine in the streets; all joy is darkened, the mirth of the land is gone.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the city is left desolation, and the gate is smitten with destruction.
speaker: Narrator

text: When thus it shall be in the midst of the land among the people, there shall be as the shaking of an olive tree, and as the gleaning of grapes when the vintage is done.
speaker: Narrator

text: They shall lift up their voice, they shall sing; for the majesty of the Lord, they shall cry aloud from the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore glorify ye the Lord in the valleys, even the name of the Lord God of Israel in the isles of the sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the uttermost part of the earth have we heard songs, even glory to the righteous. But I said, “My leanness, my leanness, woe unto me! The treacherous dealers have dealt treacherously, yea, the treacherous dealers have dealt very treacherously.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Fear and the pit and the snare are upon thee, O inhabitant of the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it shall come to pass that he who fleeth from the noise of the fear shall fall into the pit, and he that cometh up out of the midst of the pit shall be taken in the snare; for the windows from on high are open, and the foundations of the earth do shake.
speaker: Narrator

text: The earth is utterly broken down, the earth is clean dissolved, the earth is moved exceedingly.
speaker: Narrator

text: The earth shall reel to and fro like a drunkard, and shall be removed like a cottage; and the transgression thereof shall be heavy upon it; and it shall fall, and not rise again.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it shall come to pass in that day that the Lord shall punish the host of the high ones that are on high, and the kings of the earth upon the earth.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they shall be gathered together, as prisoners are gathered in the pit, and shall be shut up in the prison, and after many days shall they be visited.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the moon shall be confounded and the sun ashamed, when the Lord of hosts shall reign in Mount Zion and in Jerusalem and before His elders gloriously.
speaker: Narrator

text: O Lord, Thou art my God. I will exalt Thee, I will praise Thy name, for Thou hast done wonderful things; Thy counsels of old are faithfulness and truth.
speaker: Narrator

text: For Thou hast made of a city a heap, of a fortified city a ruin, a palace of strangers to be no city; it shall never be rebuilt.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore shall the strong people glorify Thee; the city of the terrible nations shall fear Thee.
speaker: Narrator

text: For Thou hast been a strength to the poor, a strength to the needy in his distress, a refuge from the storm, a shadow from the heat, when the blast of the terrible ones is as a storm against the wall.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thou shalt bring down the noise of strangers, as the heat in a dry place, even the heat with the shadow of a cloud; the branch of the terrible ones shall be brought low.
speaker: Narrator

text: And in this mountain shall the Lord of hosts make unto all people a feast of fat things, a feast of wines on the lees, of fat things full of marrow, of wines on the lees well refined.
speaker: Narrator

text: And He will destroy in this mountain the face of the covering cast over all people, and the veil that is spread over all nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: He will swallow up death in victory; and the Lord God will wipe away tears from off all faces, and the rebuke of His people shall He take away from off all the earth; for the Lord hath spoken it.
speaker: Narrator

text: And it shall be said in that day: “Lo, this is our God; we have waited for Him, and He will save us. This is the Lord; we have waited for Him; we will be glad and rejoice in His salvation.”
speaker: Narrator

text: For in this mountain shall the hand of the Lord rest, and Moab shall be trodden down under Him, even as straw is trodden down for the dunghill.
speaker: Narrator

text: And He shall spread forth His hands in the midst of them, as he that swimmeth spreadeth forth his hands to swim; and He shall bring down their pride together with the spoils of their hands.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the fortress of the high fort of thy walls shall He bring down, lay low, and bring to the ground, even to the dust.
speaker: Narrator
